He said the company had agreed to set up a "sovereign fund" to compensate victims, but had "agreed not to establish a fund of its own." The news comes as Adjusters pass out emergency funds in Louisiana and other Gulf Coast states "on high alert for fraud even as they pay out legitimate claims," reports the Times-Picayune of New Orleans.

– BP's new CEO said the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico was a "wake-up call" for the entire industry, and said the company would set up a $20 billion compensation fund for victims, reports the Wall Street Journal. The news comes as BP reported a second-quarter loss of $4.5 billion and said it would set up the fund within a month.

– The BP oil spill has put a major wrench in Norway’s plans to open its Arctic waters to oil and gas drilling. The country’s long-standing support for drilling in the region has been shaken by the spill, which could open the region to oil exploration for the first time since the 1960s, Reuters reports. Norway’s government is considering opening its Arctic waters to drilling for the first time since the end of the Cold War, but the industry says the spill will delay a decision on opening the waters to drilling.

– BP's chief executive said today that the damage from the Gulf oil spill will be at least as bad as the spill itself, and that the cost of dealing with it will be "in the ballpark" of $1.3 billion. The news comes as BP announced that the cost of dealing with the spill has risen to about $5 billion, reports the Wall Street Journal.

– The "dead zone" at the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico has now covered 7,722 square miles—about the size of Massachusetts—and overlaps areas hit by oil from BP's broken Macondo well. The area of hypoxia, or low levels of oxygen, extended far into Texas waters and is one of the largest ever found in the Gulf, researchers from the Louisiana Universities Marine Consortium said in a statement, according to Reuters.

– Alabama's attorney general has filed a lawsuit against BP, Halliburton, and Transocean for their roles in the Gulf oil spill. The lawsuit, which names BP, Halliburton, and Transocean as defendants, seeks to force the companies to pay for the "catastrophic harm" the spill has caused the state, the Washington Post reports. The lawsuit will be filed in federal court in New Orleans.

– The dispersant used in the cleanup of the BP oil spill may have actually slowed the flow of oil into the Gulf of Mexico by as much as 30%, a government expert tells the Washington Post. The Deepwater Horizon rig was drilling five miles below the surface at the time of the explosion that killed 11 workers and set off the spill. The dispersant used in the cleanup may have actually slowed the flow of oil by as much as 30%, the expert says.

– The damage from the BP oil spill is still visible in the Gulf of Mexico, and scientists say that's because the oil has been eaten by microbes. The micro- organisms were apparently stimulated by the oil spill, and they degraded the hydrocarbons so efficiently that the plume is now undetectable, said Terry Hazen of the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. "It's like a black hole in the ocean," he told the New York Times.

– BP will be kicked out of a major stock index after its massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. The move to the FTSE4Good index will take effect at the end of the month, the Financial Times reports. The move follows BP’s announcement today that the oil spill will delay its third-quarter results by at least three months.

– BP's compensation plan for the Gulf of Mexico oil spill will likely exceed the $20 billion the company has put into an independent claims fund, a Citigroup analyst said after a meeting with incoming CEO Bob Dudley. The analyst said he believes claims will be less than the $20 billion the company has put into the Independent Claim Fund, Reuters reports. "Given current estimates of claims the $ 20 billion Independent Claim Fund established probably exceeds calls," the analyst said in a research note.

– BP CEO Tony Hayward is facing tough questions from British lawmakers today about the company's safety record in the wake of the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. “It’s been easy for some parties to suggest that this is a problem with BP,” Hayward told a parliamentary committee, according to the Telegraph. But he said the spill was actually the result of industry failings, not BP’s, and said the company was committed to safety. “It’s been easy for some parties to suggest that this is a problem with BP,” he said.

– The final shot of BP's Gulf of Mexico oil well was made today by the remotely operated vehicles known as remotely operated vehicles, or ROVs, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports. BP said the cement was removed from the well earlier today, and the ROVs will remain at the site for a few days to watch for signs of damage. Reuters has video of the final shot here.

– The BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico will have little or no effect on the medium-term outlook for offshore drilling and supplies, the International Energy Agency tells Reuters. The IEA, a branch of the International Energy Agency, is the world's leading energy watchdog.

– BP's incoming CEO Bob Dudley has promised a major overhaul of the company's operations after its disastrous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Dudley, who will take over from Tony Hayward next month, has been responsible for overseeing BP's response to the spill and will now oversee the company's safety operations, the Telegraph reports. “I am confident that under the new structure BP will be in a better position to deal with future risks and challenges,” said Dudley. “The safety of our people and the integrity of our operations will be of the utmost importance to us.”

– Researchers have found alarming levels of cancer and other toxins in the Gulf of Mexico affected by the BP oil spill, reports the New York Times. The findings were based on samples taken off the coast of Louisiana in August—the last sampling date before BP's Deepwater Horizon well was capped in July. The toxic chemicals were found at "alarming" levels, said one of the researchers, who warned that the effects of the spill on human health could be long-lasting.

– The world's biggest-ever study of its oceans has come up with thousands of new species, including a 23-foot-long squid, reports the New York Times. The 10-year study, which involved 2,700 experts in 80 nations, also found luminous fish in the sunless depths, a shrimp thought extinct in Jurassic times, and hairy-clawed yeti crab, reports Reuters.

– The Obama administration was “over-optimistic” about BP’s ability to handle the Gulf oil spill, and relied too much on the oil giant, according to a report from the National Oil Spill Commission released today. The report found that the administration relied too much on BP and didn’t take enough action to stop the spill, the Washington Post reports.

– BP's internal investigation into the Gulf oil spill was "absolutely inadequate," Shell's chief executive said today. Peter Voser told an Oil and Money conference in London that BP's report didn't examine the thinking behind the particular well design BP used—something BP's report did not consider, the Wall Street Journal reports.

– BP will waive the legal cap on its liability for the Gulf oil spill in a bid to boost its reputation, the company said in a court filing today. The move will allow BP to limit its liability to 75 million dollars, plus cleanup costs, the Wall Street Journal reports. BP also said it will freeze executive pay for a year.

– BP's efforts to plug its massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico have so far only succeeded in releasing a small percentage of the oil—or, in the words of the head of BP America, "only a very small percentage of the oil." The news comes as a federal judge in New Orleans ordered the oil giant to hold off on drilling deeper into the Gulf until at least mid-November to assess the damage, reports the New York Times. The judge also ordered BP to pay a fine of at least $200,000 for each day the spill continues.

– BP's new CEO has a message for critics of the company's handling of the Gulf oil spill: It's your fault. Bob Dudley said rivals and the media had a hand in causing a "climate of fear" in the US during the spill, Reuters reports. "I don't think there's ever been a more critical time in the industry's history for the safety of our people and the environment," he said. "The media and others have had a very significant impact on the perception of BP and its role in the Gulf spill. I don't think there's ever been a more critical time in the industry's history for the safety of our people and the environment."

– Halliburton used flawed cement in BP's doomed Gulf of Mexico well, which could have contributed to the blowout that sparked the worst offshore oil spill in US history, according to documents obtained by the Wall Street Journal. The documents show that BP used five different kinds of cement in the well, including one that was supposed to withstand pressures of 5,000 pounds per square inch but was only able to withstand pressures of 3,000 pounds per square inch. The blowout preventer was only able to withstand pressures of 3,000 pounds per square inch. Halliburton, BP's primary contractor on the well, said in a statement that the cement was tested and approved to withstand pressures of 5,000 pounds per square inch. But BP said in a statement to the New York Times that the cement was only approved to withstand pressures of 3,000 pounds per square inch.

– BP's third-quarter earnings beat analysts' estimates by a wide margin and the company increased its estimate of the cost of the Gulf oil spill to 40 billion dollars. The British oil giant's underlying profits were up slightly as well, to $6.6 billion from $6.2 billion a year earlier, reports the Wall Street Journal.

– BP's massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico will take at least three months to plug, the head of the federal oil spill commission said today. Thad Allen told a Senate panel that the spill could take as long as a year to plug. "It's going to take time," he said. "It's going to take BP a long time to plug. It's going to take engineers a long time to plug. It's going to take them a long time to shut off the well." Allen said the Coast Guard will work with BP to slow the flow of oil into the Gulf. He said the Coast Guard will set up a command center in New Orleans to work with BP and others to plug the well.

– BP's former CEO today defended his company's handling of the Gulf oil spill in an interview with the Christian Science Monitor. "I'm not going to get into the internal squabbles between BP and the federal government, but I'm not going to get into the internal squabbles between BP and the state of Louisiana," said Tony Hayward. Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal, meanwhile, accused the White House of "political posturing" and "lackadaisical" response to the spill in his new book, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune.

– BP's $20 billion Gulf oil spill fund may soon be in the hands of BP itself. The fund's administrator, Kenneth Feinberg, is circulating a proposal that would allow the fund's claimants to transfer their right to sue other defendants to BP, the Wall Street Journal reports. The move would also allow BP to collect billions of dollars from its business partners. The proposal is part of a final set of rules being circulated by Feinberg, who is overseeing the release of cash to shrimpers, hotel owners, restaurateurs, and others on the Gulf Coast seeking compensation.

– The administrator of BP's $20 billion fund for victims of the worst oil spill in US history is set to announce a fund of his own. Harold Hamm will announce the fund at a news conference in Houston today, reports the Houston Chronicle. The news conference will be followed by a Q&A session.

– BP's third-quarter loss widened to $7.7 billion as the oil giant set aside another $8.6 billion to cover the damage from the Gulf oil spill. The British company's shares rose 4.5% in early trading on the London Stock Exchange. BP's new chief executive Bob Dudley said the company was on the right track and expected to return to profitability in the fourth quarter, reports the Wall Street Journal.

– The White House oil spill commission said today that BP told them the government's final estimate of oil flow was between 53,400 and 60,000 barrels per day—about 20% to 50% too high, reports the Wall Street Journal. BP said the government estimate was based on information from Halliburton, which was drilling the well at the time.

– BP's "breathtakingly inept" handling of the Gulf oil spill has led to a new headache for the oil giant: a Houston company that could be the first to respond to a deepwater oil spill. Helix Energy Solutions Group is building a system of vessels and equipment similar to those used during BP's massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the New York Times reports. The system will be similar to the one that BP used during the spill, and Helix says it will be able to use the same equipment in a similar way.

– It's that time of year again: time for the Macy's Thanksgiving Parade to begin. This year's parade will be held on the National Mall in Washington, DC. It will be the first time in more than a decade that the parade has not been held on the National Mall in Washington, DC, reports the Washington Post, which notes that the last time the parade was held on the National Mall in Washington was in 2004.

– The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell more than 100 points in the first minutes of trading today, led by a steep drop in shares of Dow component Exxon Mobil, reports the Wall Street Journal. The Dow has fallen more than 500 points in the past three days. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq have also fallen in early trading.

– The world's top three insurance brokers—Aon Benfield, Munich Re, and Lloyd's of London—have teamed up to offer a one-of-a-kind oil spill insurance program. The program, called SOSCover, will offer up to $1 billion in cover for the world's biggest oil spills and will be managed by Aon Benfield, which will also provide spill-management services. "It's a unique opportunity to offer a comprehensive insurance solution to the oil industry," Aon Benfield's chief executive tells Reuters.

– Stephen Baldwin and a friend are suing Costner and his company for scamming them out of millions of dollars, reports the Hollywood Reporter. Costner's company, CINC, claimed to have developed a technology that separated oil from water. Baldwin and his friend sold their shares in the company.

– The final report from the White House oil spill commission blames BP for much of the Gulf oil spill and calls the company's efforts to plug the well "irresponsible," reports the New York Times. The report also points the finger at TransOcean, the owner of the well, for its slow response to the spill. TransOcean shares rose as much as 6% in pre-market trading on the report's findings, Reuters reports.

– The Washington Post is out with its annual list of the 100 worst companies to work for in the oil and gas industry. This year's list includes BP (No. 1), Halliburton (No. 2), Schlumberger (No. 3), and Occidental Petroleum (No. 4). The top 10: Halliburton (No. 1) BP (No. 2) Halliburton (No. 3) Schlumberger (No. 3) Occidental Petroleum (No. 4) Occidental Petroleum (No. 4) Click for the full list.

– The co-chairs of the White House oil spill commission made their case for legislation to prevent a repeat of last year's massive BP oil spill at two congressional hearings today. Democrats pressed for new legislation aimed at preventing a repeat of last year's massive BP oil spill, as Republicans warned that the disaster should not be used to hamper offshore oil and natural gas production. The renewed push to boost government oversight of offshore drilling came as the co-chairs of the White House oil spill commission, Bill Reilly and Bob Graham, made their case for legislation on the issue at two separate congressional hearings.

– The Coast Guard has taken the unprecedented step of sending in a remotely operated vehicle to survey the damage in the Gulf of Mexico, the AP reports. The remotely operated vehicle, or ROV, has been used before, but this is the first time it has been used by the Coast Guard. The ROV is similar to the one used by the Navy to survey the damage at Pearl Harbor.

– The blowout preventer that failed to stop the Deepwater Horizon oil spill had a dead battery, leaks in its hydraulic system, and a "test version of a key component and a cutting tool that was not strong enough to shear through steel joints in the well pipe and stop the flow of oil," according to a scathing report from the House Energy panel. BP's head of US operations, Lamar McKay, told the panel that the blowout preventer was a "work of art" and the company "failed miserably," reports the New York Times. Rep. Ed Markey, meanwhile, said the report showed that the blowout preventer "was not at the top of the list of safety features that should have been in place."

– The Coast Guard has taken the unprecedented step of going door to door in Mississippi, Alabama, and Louisiana to talk to residents about the dangers of the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the Clarion-Ledger reports. The newspaper says it's the first time the Coast Guard has gone door to door to talk to people about the environmental impact of a large-scale spill in the state. The idea is to get the word out to residents so they can make informed decisions about their own safety and that of their families and friends.

– The Coast Guard is ready to open an all-out assault on the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports. Coast Guard Commandant Thad Allen says his team is ready to use "whatever tools are necessary" to fight the spill, which is on track to reach Louisiana within days. The Coast Guard has set up a command center in New Orleans.

– The Coast Guard has told BP to intensify its efforts to contain the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, reports the Times-Picayune of New Orleans. Interior Secretary Ken Salazar has met with BP execs to discuss the company's plans for dealing with the spill, which is on its way to Louisiana.

– The Coast Guard has deployed two ships to contain the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports. The ships are armed with remotely operated vehicles that can stop the flow of oil, and the Coast Guard has set up a command center in New Orleans, the Washington Post reports. President Obama is flying in for a briefing today.

– BP's chief executive will face a Senate panel today to answer questions about the Gulf oil spill and the company's preparedness for it, reports the Washington Post. Other execs from the company and Transocean, owner of the rig that exploded, will also be in the room for the hearing, which begins at 10am EDT. BP says it has capped one of the three leaks in the pipe from the damaged oil well in the Gulf of Mexico, but the company said doing so would simplify the problems on the sea floor it would not alter the rate at which crude oil is spilling into the gulf. Click here for more.

– BP finally began siphoning oil from the gushing well in the Gulf of Mexico today, in what the Washington Post calls a “rare bulletin of good news” about 312 weeks into the spill. The company began by inserting a tube into the leaking pipe, and began siphoning some of the oil to a drilling rig at the surface. The deep sea plumbing did not do anything to close the well, and a substantial amount of oil continues to leak at the bottom of the gulf, but the day’s efforts were a rare bulletin of good news about 31/2 weeks into the crisis.

– The White House has set up an independent commission to investigate the BP oil spill, reports the Washington Post. Current and former federal officials will not be on the panel, which will be similar to panels that investigated the space shuttle Challenger explosion and the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island, notes the New York Times.

– The Coast Guard has found at least 11 injured or dead animals in the Gulf of Mexico so far from the BP oil spill, reports the Times-Picayune of New Orleans. The animals include sea otters, sea turtles, birds, fish, and mammals. The extent of the damage to wildlife is unknown, but officials fear that many of the injured and dead animals have not been reported to authorities. Click here for the latest on the spill.

– Interior Secretary Ken Salazar is "angry and I am frustrated" that BP hasn't been able to seal its blown-out oil well in the Gulf of Mexico, reports the New York Times. "We are 33 days into this effort, and deadline after deadline has been missed," Salazar said yesterday after visiting BP's headquarters in Houston. Salazar said the administration is considering taking control of the spill from BP, reports the Washington Post.

– The Coast Guard has told BP that it can't proceed with the so-called "top kill" operation until it has been sure that the blowout preventer is functioning, reports the New York Times. The Coast Guard has told BP that it can't proceed with the operation until it has been sure that the blowout preventer is functioning, reports the Washington Post, which notes that the Coast Guard has told BP that it can't proceed with the operation until it has been sure that the blowout preventer is functioning.

– The failed "top kill" attempt at the Gulf of Mexico has set off a wave of criticism against BP and the Obama administration. BP "is coming in for plenty of abuse these days, and certainly much of it is deserved," writes Ed Rogers at the Washington Post. "Why were we drilling in 5,000 feet of water in the first place? Many reasons, but this one goes unmentioned: Environmental chic has driven us out there," he writes. "As production from the shallower Gulf of Mexico wells declines, we go deep—LRB- 1,000 feet and more—RRB- and ultra deep—LRB- 5,000 feet and more, in part because environmentalists have succeeded in rendering the Pacific and nearly all the Atlantic coast off—limits to oil production."

– The White House has distanced itself from BP in the wake of the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the New York Times reports. The administration is also sending Attorney General Eric Holder to the Gulf to oversee the cleanup, and President Obama is holding a White House briefing on the spill today. The spill is also a moral crisis, writes Sally Quinn and Jon Meacham in the Washington Post. "Is it also a moral crisis?" asks Quinn. "How does religion influence our use and abuse of the natural world? Does religion help or harm the environment? It is a matter of interpretation Explore all of our oil spill graphics to track the spill, see its effects, and learn its possible solutions."

– The White House has told BP to pay for the growing oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the New York Times reports. President Obama has also demanded that the oil giant pony up for cleanup efforts, and the administration is considering taking BP to court to force it to clean up the mess. The White House has also told BP to pay for the construction of five more large sections of Louisiana barrier island sand berms, the Times reports. The spill has already closed oyster beds, shut down shrimpers, canceled fishing tournaments, and panicked beach hoteliers from New Orleans to Key West.

– As the Gulf Coast cleans up from the BP oil spill, the New Orleans Times-Picayune takes a look at the environmental impact of the spill and at the company that caused it. BP has been known to disregard safety and environmental rules, and internal investigations have revealed a rash of problems at BP's Alaska oil—drilling operations—over the past decade, reports the New York Times, which notes that 80% of the Gulf's recent oil production has come from deepwater drilling. Click here for more on the spill.

– BP's stock price has plunged more than 15% in the wake of the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. The stock price of BP plunged more than 15% today to a 14-year low as the amount of oil spewing out of the Deepwater Horizon well is substantially greater than the company or the federal government initially estimated. Coast Guard Adm Before the spill, the Obama administration lifted the moratorium on drilling in US Why is oil spill hard to predict? Look to the clouds. Oil pools along Barataria Bay on the Louisiana coast Pick a number: 12,600 barrels. 20,000 Louisiana Rep. Charlie Melancon moved to tears by gulf spill Grand ISLE, La.

– President Obama and BP CEO Tony Hayward met privately at the White House today to discuss the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, reports the Washington Post. Obama, for his part, said it was "good news" that BP will set up a $20 billion escrow account to pay spill-related claims. "I was talking to in the gulf that BP will meet its responsibilities," he said. "We're going to make sure that BP is paying the bill."

– President Obama and BP CEO Tony Hayward both apologized for the Gulf oil spill in public appearances at the White House yesterday. "I am deeply sorry for the lost lives and environmental damage from my company's doomed offshore rig," said Hayward. "It is not easy to divvy up $ 20 billion. Perhaps no one in America knows this better than Kenneth Feinberg." BP will set up a $20 billion escrow account to pay spill claims, reports the Washington Post. "We are deeply sorry," said BP chairman Carl Svanberg. "And we care about the small people."

– Kent Wells, BP's senior vice president in charge of the Gulf oil spill cleanup, said today that the company will set up a $20 billion fund to pay for the spill, reports the New York Times. "We're going to do everything we can to contain the oil and make sure it is cleaned up," he said during a House Energy and Environment subcommittee hearing. "I'm not going to get into who is ultimately responsible for this, but I can tell you that we have a system in place that is robust and robust and robust to prevent this from happening in the first place." BP has also assembled a formidable team of Democrats for its Washington lobbying, legal, and public relations efforts, notes the Los Angeles Times.

– The live spillcam shows yet more oil pouring into the Gulf of Mexico, and the Obama administration is considering taking control of the spill from BP, reports the Washington Post. White House energy czar Carol Browner said the administration is considering taking control of the spill from BP, which is responsible for the cleanup, and from Halliburton, which is responsible for the blowout preventer, reports the New York Times.

– Those receiving payments from BP for the Gulf oil spill will have to pay up on their taxes, the IRS said today. Under current law, BP payments for lost wages are taxable—just as the wages would have been, the IRS said. The development comes as new BP CEO Bob Dudley made his first public appearance since the spill, notes the Washington Post.

– BP says it won't make political contributions, "whether in cash or in kind, anywhere in the world," according to its own code of conduct. But the Washington Post reports that the company has donated $4,850 to US political candidates and PACs since the Deepwater Horizon spill, even though its code says it won't "make political contributions in any country in the world." The Post also notes that BP has funneled tens of millions of dollars into an organization set up to provide cleanup equipment and personnel if a catastrophic offshore spill ever hits the US. But when that spill occurred two months ago, it soon swamped the Marine Spill Response Corp despite BP corporate code, the paper reports.

– As the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico threatens to become the biggest in US history, the Obama administration is taking a hard look at its policies on the environment and offshore drilling, reports the New York Times. The White House is considering a host of new restrictions on drilling, including a cap that could slow the spill down by up to 30%, reports the Washington Post. The newspaper also looks at the mechanics of the spill, including BP's inability to control the flow.

– The White House has sought to distance itself from BP in the wake of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, but the two sides are working hand in hand on an assessment of the damage the spill has done to the Gulf of Mexico, the New York Times reports. The gulf has been examined by an armada of researchers—from federal agencies, universities, and nonprofit groups—and they do not appear close to answering the most important question of the spill: How dead is the Gulf of Mexico? It is perhaps the most important question of the BP oil spill—but scientists do not appear close to answering it despite a historically vast effort. In the 77 days since oil from the ruptured Deepwater Horizon began to gush into the Gulf of Mexico, BP has skimmed or burned about 60% of the amount it promised regulators it could remove in a single day. The disparity between what BP promised in its March 24 filing with federal regulators and the amount of oil recovered since the April 20 explosion underscores what some officials and environmental groups call a misleading numbers game that has led to widespread confusion about the extent of the spill and the progress of the recovery.

– The live video feed from BP's Deepwater Horizon oil well continues to show the oil pouring into the Gulf of Mexico, reports the Washington Post. The live video feed, which is expected to continue for at least 24 hours, is a big part of the company's strategy for containing the spill, notes the New York Times. The live video feed is a big part of the company's plan to change caps on the well, a tricky task that could greatly improve the ability to capture the oil or perhaps shut down the well—but that would permit oil to flow during the switch.

– BP finally installed a new cap on its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico yesterday, but the plan has been delayed until at least Wednesday because of a court order that keeps the company from pumping in heavy mud to plug the well. The New York Times, which first reported the new cap's installation, reports that the procedure to seal the well is likely to take at least a day, and that it will be at least a day before engineers know for sure whether it will work.

– The Coast Guard is investigating the cause of the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. BP's Macondo well remains a threat to gush anew, and "very much alive until it is plugged with cement in a bottom—kill that's still weeks away at best," writes Michael S. Fahrenthold at the Washington Post.

– The Coast Guard's Thad Allen says BP's latest attempt to contain the oil in the Gulf of Mexico may begin this weekend. The plan is to pump mud into the top of the well, a procedure known as a "static kill" that could take up to a month, reports the New York Times. Allen said the procedure, which involves shooting mud into the top of the well, could be done as early as tomorrow. BP says the procedure has worked so far, and it plans to continue for at least 24 hours to monitor it.

– BP's CEO says the oil giant has taken down an image that appears to have been altered using photo editing software, the AP reports. CEO Tony Hayward said in a video posted on BP's website that the company has taken down the image "out of an abundance of caution."

– The Coast Guard has begun evacuating rig workers from the site of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico ahead of the expected final kill of the well next week, reports the Times-Picayune. The Coast Guard has also set up a command center in New Orleans. BP has said it will kill the well by the end of this week, but the last of the rig's workers will have to evacuate before that happens, notes the Washington Post.

– Chemical dispersants sprayed into the Gulf of Mexico to break up the massive oil spill do not appear to threaten the safety of seafood in the affected waters, the Food and Drug Administration said this week. The White House has announced that three—fours of the oil that leaked into the Gulf of Mexico from BP's Macondo well is contained— evaporated, skimmed, collected, burned off, dispersed or dissolved, reports the Detroit Free Press.

– BP's board is expected to announce today that it has picked Robert Dudley as its new CEO, reports the Wall Street Journal. Dudley, currently the company's head of exploration for the Gulf, will take over for CEO Tony Hayward, who is expected to step down sometime in the next few weeks. The 52-year-old is a native of Mississippi, and has been with the company since 1983, notes the New York Times.

– The plan is to pump mud into the gushing Gulf well in an effort to seal it, but it could take up to a day to do so, reports the New York Times. The first part of the plan is to pump mud into the well, followed by a "static kill" in which mud and cement is placed on the top of the well to seal it. BP says the first part of the plan could take up to a day.

– BP finished pumping cement into the blown-out Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico as part of its efforts to permanently plug the source of the nation's worst oil spill, the company said today. Engineers started cementing the operation at 10:15am local time, the New York Times reports. The procedure to pump heavy mud into the well has succeeded in plugging it, officials said yesterday, and government scientists reported that most of the crude that gushed from it for three months has dissipated or been removed from the water. President Obama cautioned that much recovery work remains, and other officials warned that the threat from the damaged Macondo well will not be eliminated until it is killed later this month with a relief well BP's fight against energy nonprofit highlights murky world of advocacy—for—hire Days after the Deepwater Horizon oil rig sank in the Gulf of Mexico, a conservative nonprofit group called the Institute for Energy Research asked BP to contribute $100,000 for a media campaign it was launching in defense of the oil industry. Although BP took a pass, the group's advocacy arm went ahead with a campaign—only instead of defending BP, it vilified the company as a "safety outlier" in an otherwise safe industry.

– – The Coast Guard has set up a command center in Grand Isle, La., to monitor the effects of the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the Times-Picayune reports. The Coast Guard says it has set up a command center in New Orleans and is sending a boat, a helicopter, and a remotely operated vehicle to the Gulf to monitor the spill, the AP reports. The blowout preventer that was installed at the site of the spill is being removed.

– Transocean, owner of the sunken Deepwater Horizon rig, fired off a scathing letter to BP yesterday, accusing the oil giant of hoarding information and test results related to the Deepwater Horizon blowout, the Washington Post reports. Transocean fired off the letter in response to the Obama administration's assertion that most of BP's oil is either gone or rapidly disappearing. The administration has said that most of the oil is either gone or rapidly disappearing. BP and Transocean are in an increasingly bitter battle over what went wrong on April 20 to trigger America's worst oil spill.

– The blowout preventer at BP's Gulf of Mexico well was not installed properly, a blowout preventer expert told a federal panel investigating the Deepwater Horizon disaster yesterday. Kent Wells, BP's senior vice president for exploration and production, said the blowout preventer was installed in May at the same time as the blowout preventer, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports. "The blowout preventer was installed at the same time as the remotely operated vehicle," Wells said. "TheROV was installed at the same time as the blowout preventer. The blowout preventer was not operated at the same time as the remotely operated vehicle." Investigators also cited a 2003 letter to Wells from the federal Minerals Management Service that blasted BP for "incomplete planning, poor communication, insufficient knowledge or training, and a lack of effective supervision."

– BP says it has spent more than $5 million a week on advertising since the Gulf oil spill—more than three times the amount it spent on ads during the same period last year, reports the Washington Post. The company told a House committee yesterday that it spent a total of $93 million on ads from April to the end of July. The spending comes as BP released a document called "Lessons Learned," which the company says offers a "new spirit of collaboration" in containing future oil rig failures.

– BP's internal report on the Gulf oil spill is out, and the company is taking most of the blame for the mess. The report, obtained by the New York Times, says the blowout preventer failed, leading to the worst oil spill in US history. The report also notes that BP's equipment failed, leading to the worst-case scenario of an uncontrolled spill that could spill up to 5,000 barrels of oil a day, the AP reports. BP says it will set up a $20 billion compensation fund for victims.

– The results of BP's internal investigation into the Deepwater Horizon oil spill are in, and they don't appear to show that the company cut corners in order to save money, the New York Times reports. "My view is that we did not see any indications that we did n't see any indications that support that," said the investigation's chief investigator, Mark Bly. The report, which BP says is the first comprehensive look at the cause of the spill, is expected to be released in a matter of days.

– A federal judge has ordered BP to clean up the Gulf of Mexico in the wake of the massive oil spill, and the company has agreed to do so, the New York Times reports. The judge also ordered BP to pay damages to the state of Louisiana, which has been hard-hit by the spill, and to pay damages to the fishermen and others who have been affected by it.

– BP has agreed to join forces with Exxon, Chevron, ConocoPhillips, and Royal Dutch Shell in the event of an oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the New York Times reports. The oil giant says it will spend $1 billion to create equipment and train teams for the spill response. The other four companies said they would spend the same amount on training and equipment for the spill response.

– New BP CEO Bob Dudley is making some changes in the wake of the Gulf oil spill, reports the Wall Street Journal. Among them: The chief of exploration and production, Doug Suttles, will no longer oversee the company's response to the spill. The other three responsibilities have been split among three other BP executives, notes the New York Times. Suttles, for his part, told the Oil Spill Commission that "some of the tools and techniques available to use were the same ones available 20 years ago."

– Thad W. Allen can finally retire now. The Miami Herald reports that the NBA's Miami Heat will play the Houston Rockets in the second game of a second-round playoff series on Friday night. The game will be held at the AmericanAirlines Arena in Miami.

– President Obama's National Commission on the BP Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill and Offshore Drilling released preliminary reports today that criticize the administration's handling of the spill, the New York Times reports. The reports say the White House created the impression that it was either "not fully competent" or "not fully candid with the American people about the scope of the problem," notes the Washington Post.

– The New York Times is out with a story on President Obama's decision to allow more drilling on US waters, and it's not pretty. The story, by fact-checker Frank Thorp, says the White House has been slow to consult with environmental groups on the plan. "The president has been very clear that this is not a carte blanche for drilling," writes Thorp. "But the White House has been very slow to consult with environmental groups on this issue, and that is a big problem."

– BP's latest attempt to contain the Gulf oil spill ran into technical obstacles over the weekend that increased the likelihood of a prolonged battle to stop the leak, reports the New York Times. The company's chief executive, Tony Hayward, told a Senate hearing yesterday that the "urgency" to stop the spill has been growing since the beginning of the week. "We have been unable to contain the oil," he said. "We have been unable to slow the flow of the oil. It is going to take a lot of time." Hayward and other BP execs will be in Capitol Hill today for a Senate hearing on the spill.

– Relief workers from around the world are en route to Haiti to help in the wake of the country's devastating earthquake. The first foreign rescue team is en route to Port-au-Prince from the Dominican Republic, the BBC reports. The International Rescue Corps, a Scottish rescue group, has warned that it faces bankruptcy if it goes to Haiti because it can't afford the trip. Wyclef Jean has called on fans to donate to relief efforts.

– The death toll from the Haiti earthquake now stands at 50,000, according to the country's interior minister, and that number is sure to rise. The toll includes tens of thousands of children who have been orphaned by the disaster, reports the BBC. The toll is sure to rise as aid gets into the hands of thousands of survivors in a country that has received just $15 million in aid so far.

– Relief workers in Haiti are still struggling to get food, water, and medical supplies to survivors, and the country's interior minister says 100,000 people will initially be sent to 10 settlements near Port-au-Prince. Prince Haiti is planning to house 400,000 earthquake survivors in new tented villages outside the capital, the BBC reports. Interior Minister Paul Bien-Aime said 100,000 people would initially be sent to 10 settlements near the suburb of Croix Des Bouquets. International aid agencies have raised concerns about what is happening, and the UN has described it as the worst disaster it has ever been involved in.
